docs.abstract: Trial and error leads to the perfect Filipino dessert.
docs.snippet: Trial and error leads to the perfect Filipino dessert.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of each school year, Margarita Manzke and her seven siblings piled into the family car in Manila, where her father ran a fish-sauce factory, to drive to her mother’s resort in Subic Bay, on the west coast of Luzon, about two hours away. They spent summers there, not swimming and sunbathing like other families on vacation from the city. Not bobbing down the waves on boogie boards, or falling asleep under umbrellas with books in one hand and drinks in the other. Even as a teenager, Manzke was an entrepreneur. And summertime, free from the structure of daily classes and homework, was for one thing, and one thing only: engaging in the sport of friendly competition with her brothers and sisters.

headline.main: These Date-and-Walnut Bars Are Food for the Gods

docs.abstract: In a time when everyone seems devoted to a different set of facts, the secret recording has come to seem like the gold standard of hard evidence.
docs.snippet: In a time when everyone seems devoted to a different set of facts, the secret recording has come to seem like the gold standard of hard evidence.
docs.lead_paragraph: Would you trust Tom Arnold on the topic of national politics — or, really, on anything at all? Arnold is one of many former stars to wash back into public consciousness via the rise of his fellow down-list celebrity Donald Trump. He has restyled himself as an expert on the president’s one-time Hollywood milieu, speaking widely about his personal and professional run-ins with Trump and, more recently, claiming that Trump used wildly abusive and racist language on the set of “The Apprentice.” But Arnold knows we won’t take his word for this.

headline.main: Nothing Proves You Right Like Getting It on ‘Tape’

docs.abstract: The writer and actor on HBO’s “Insecure” on rom-coms and black-girl magic.
docs.snippet: The writer and actor on HBO’s “Insecure” on rom-coms and black-girl magic.
docs.lead_paragraph: You’re a writer and an actor on HBO’s “Insecure,” which is now in its third season. Did you have any idea of how big the show would be when you first started working on it? I didn’t know just how much of a cultural phenomenon it would become. I just knew that, as a person of color, I had not seen these specific stories told before. When you think of “Girlfriends” or “Living Single” — they’re these extraordinary black women! But there are a lot of ordinary women who have ordinary problems. It’s not black-girl magic all the time — sometimes you don’t know where your wand is. You’re like, “Today I have no magic, and I have no money, and I just have to get through the day.”

headline.main: Natasha Rothwell Wants to Be a Romantic Lead
headline.print_headline: Natasha Rothwell Wants to Be a Romantic Lead

docs.lead_paragraph: A sudden summer storm, cushions and laundry caught out in the rain — the scene feels familiar, although these details stem from Tishani Doshi’s memories of monsoon season in India, under “the fan-whir sea-heave/of our muscled Tamil Nadu nights.” Nature’s brusque disruption has broken the trance of routine, and for a moment the hinge between childhood and adulthood swings wide. Even as they bend to the task of reclaiming what the tempest has scattered, a trace of that wild ache lingers — a glimpse into what it means to be inconsolably, joyously human. Selected by Rita Dove

docs.abstract: Houston thought it was prepared for a major hurricane like Harvey. But as the flooding overwhelmed the city’s emergency systems, families like the Daileys found out too late that they were on their own.
docs.snippet: Houston thought it was prepared for a major hurricane like Harvey. But as the flooding overwhelmed the city’s emergency systems, families like the Daileys found out too late that they were on their own.

docs.abstract: Followers of the bizarre “QAnon” theory imagine they can follow preposterous internet hints to some great truth. But that’s rarely where a trail of crumbs takes you.
docs.snippet: Followers of the bizarre “QAnon” theory imagine they can follow preposterous internet hints to some great truth. But that’s rarely where a trail of crumbs takes you.
docs.lead_paragraph: Go hungry for too long, and a lot of strange things will start to look like food. The smallest morsels become precious, especially if you believe they form some kind of trail with a meal at the end. This is true not only of physical sustenance; it is true of knowledge as well. You always find scattered crumbs — inscrutable analogies, esoteric equations, unverified allegations from anonymous sources — gathered around those questions about which we know the least.

headline.main: A Trail of ‘Bread Crumbs,’ Leading Conspiracy Theorists Into the Wilderness

docs.abstract: With the new show ‘Maniac,’ he continues bringing an auteur’s sensibility — and a fanatical attention to detail — to the small screen.
docs.snippet: With the new show ‘Maniac,’ he continues bringing an auteur’s sensibility — and a fanatical attention to detail — to the small screen.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of 2009, the director Cary Joji Fukunaga was hunting for his second feature film. His first, “Sin Nombre,” had been an almost preposterously ambitious undertaking for a first-time filmmaker, tracking the intertwining stories of an immigrant and an erstwhile member of MS-13 as they made the dangerous journey to the United States border atop fast-moving train cars, all written by Fukunaga in slang-heavy Spanish. Over the course of two years, he made multiple trips to Mexico, riding the real-life version of these trains and visiting prisons in Chiapas to make connections with gang members who could help ensure that the film had a documentarylike accuracy. “I need to believe what I’m watching,” he says.

headline.main: ‘True Detective’ Director Cary Fukunaga Is Bringing His Obsessions to Netflix

docs.abstract: The dynamic star is trying to keep comedy alive at a moment when Hollywood — and its audience — can’t seem to crack a smile.
docs.snippet: The dynamic star is trying to keep comedy alive at a moment when Hollywood — and its audience — can’t seem to crack a smile.
docs.lead_paragraph: Melissa McCarthy was hovering six feet above Los Angeles, in a glass tube, wearing a helmet and goggles. Her limbs were spread out like a starfish, with her legs bent at the knee as if she were a teenager reading on her stomach on her bed and her arms bent at the elbow so that had she been upright, they would have made the shape of a cactus.

headline.main: This Melissa McCarthy Story Just Might (Maybe? Possibly?) Cheer You Up

docs.abstract: Thanks to ruthless discipline — and a plan long in the making — the G.O.P is carrying out a sweeping transformation of the federal judiciary.
docs.snippet: Thanks to ruthless discipline — and a plan long in the making — the G.O.P is carrying out a sweeping transformation of the federal judiciary.
docs.lead_paragraph: Donald F. McGahn, the White House counsel, stood in the gilded ballroom of Washington’s Mayflower Hotel last November to address the annual meeting of the Federalist Society. He seemed humbled, even a bit awed to be delivering the Barbara K. Olson Memorial lecture, named after the conservative lawyer who died in the Sept. 11 attacks. Noting some of the legal giants who gave the Olson lecture in years past, McGahn reflected, “You hear names like Scalia, Roberts and Gorsuch and then me; one of those names really is different than the rest.” Unlike previous speakers — to say nothing of many of those to whom he was now speaking — McGahn, himself a member of the Federalist Society, hadn’t attended an Ivy League law school; he went to Widener University, a “second tier” law school in Pennsylvania. He had never held a tenured professorship or boasted an appellate practice, much less a judgeship, that required him to think deeply about weighty constitutional issues; he specialized in the comparably mundane and technical field of campaign finance and election law. “But here we are,” McGahn said to the audience, almost apologetically. In 2015, Donald Trump hired McGahn to be the lawyer for his long-shot presidential campaign. Then, after Trump shockingly won the election, he tapped McGahn, who had proved his talent and loyalty during the campaign, to be White House counsel. Trump, in other words, had made McGahn’s wildest dreams come true. Now, McGahn told the Federalist Society, Trump was going to make their wildest dreams come true, too.

headline.main: How the Trump Administration Is Remaking the Courts

docs.abstract: Tabitha Isner has been trying to make a nearly impossible sales pitch to voters — and to the national donor class.
docs.snippet: Tabitha Isner has been trying to make a nearly impossible sales pitch to voters — and to the national donor class.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tabitha Isner’s campaign office in Dothan, Ala., is a modest one-story bungalow next to a dog-grooming shop, just across the street from the Shade Tree Mobile Homes Court. When I visited this summer, on a rainy afternoon, the living room was furnished with cheap folding tables and decorated with white boards, homemade posters and a huge Alabama flag. An Instagram-friendly letter-board sign reading GO THE EXTRA MILE was propped on the mantel over a boarded-up fireplace. The candidate herself was getting ready for an event across town, loading up her hybrid hatchback with stacks of fliers and yard signs.

headline.main: Struggling to Bring the ‘Blue Wave’ to Deep-Red Alabama
